text: Workshop description
Map making workshop-from Wiki maps in three steps
In this 90-120 minutes workshop you will learn how to make both flat, clustered, layered,embedded,interactive,on-Wiki andoff-Wiki maps from sets of geo-referenced(P625)items in Wiki data.
You will do this in 3 modules of approx. 30-40 minutes each:
Latest update:21 November 2019

The image appears to be a promotional graphic for a map-making workshop. The title of the workshop is "Map making workshop from Wikidata to interactive off-Wiki maps in three steps." It is hosted by Olaf Janssen from the National Library of the Netherlands. The image is divided into several sections: 

- The left section shows a map with numerous red markers, possibly indicating locations of interest in the Netherlands.
- The middle section features another map with different colored regions and labels, indicating administrative boundaries, possibly in Nigeria.
- The right section shows a map with colored heatmap areas, with a label for "Schoorl public library" in the Municipality of Bergen, Province of North Holland.

The bottom of the image contains contact information for Olaf Janssen and mentions the National Library of the Netherlands. There's also a logo of the National Library and a Creative Commons license mark.

text: ● Module 1: You will start by making various basic flat and clustered maps in Wikidata using SPARQL queries. Next you will make some layered maps,where groups of items can be toggled on/off in the map. ·Module 2: After having explored maps in the Wiki data query interface,you are nowready tolearnhow to embed Wikidata-driven maps in other Wikimedia projects, such as Wikipedia and Commons (examples). In addition to SPARQL wewill look at OpenStreetMap, GeoJSON and the Mediawiki Kar to graph er extension. ●Module 3: Finally you willlearn the steps for creating interactive, layered Wikidata-driven maps that can be used off- Wiki, ie. in regular HTML pages. In addtition to the above tools & techniques, we will use some basic Python, Jupyter
See the full outline of the workshop for a more detailed description.
Intended audiences

While this workshop is tech-focused and will discuss basic Wikidata, Wikipedia and Wikimedia Commons techniques and programming tools, it is meant to be approachable by beginning Wikidata contributors and programmers. The workshop leader, by no means an advanced Python programmer nor Wikidata nor SPARQL guru himself, is providing examples and code snippets that you can easily adapt yourself with basic SPARQL, Wikidata and Python skills, to make them work for your own datasets.
As the workshop is comprised of three 30-40 minute modules, you can decide to skip the modules that you find too advanced (or basic) for your individual knowledge level.
Full workshop outline & notes
Workshop outline and notes
Latest update:21 November 2019

Edit - Translate

The Kartographer extension powers interactive maps on Wikimedia wikis. This page shows techniques for creating dynamic maps by using the Kartographer tags
<mapframe> , which embeds maps right in wiki pages, and <maplink> , which creates links to dynamic maps.

The image appears to be a screenshot of a toolbar, likely from a text editing or content management system interface, displaying formatting buttons and shortcuts typically used in wikis or markup languages. Here is a description of the components in the toolbar:

1. **Standard**: A dropdown menu for selecting different formatting standards or schemes.

2. **Formatting and Syntax Elements:**
   - `[`: Start of a single bracket.
   - `[[`: Double bracket, possibly for link or page inclusion.
   - `|`: Pipe symbol, often used to separate parameters.
   - `{{`: Start of a double curly brace, often used for templates or functions.
   - `}}`: Closing of a double curly brace.
   - `–` (en dash) and `—` (em dash): Common punctuation marks.
   - `“`, `‘`, `«`, `»`: Various types of quotation marks.
   - `·` (middle dot), `•` (bullet), `×` (multiplication sign), `º` (ordinal indicator), `€` (Euro sign), `§` (section sign): Various symbols and characters.
   - `←` and `→`: Arrow symbols indicating direction.
   - `~~~`: Possible markup for author signature or similar text.

3. **Special Markup Tags:**
   - `<pre>`: Used for preformatted text.
   - ` `: Non-breaking space entity.
   - `[[Category:]]`: Syntax for adding a page to a category.
   - `[[:File:]]`: Link to a file, usually an image.
   - `[[Media:]]`: Possibly for embedding media content.
   - `{{DEFAULTSORT:}}`: Template for sorting entries in categories.
   - `{{NAMESPACE}}`: Placeholder for the current namespace.
   - `{{PAGENAME}}`: Placeholder for the current page name.
   - `#REDIRECT[[ ]]`: Syntax for redirecting from one page to another.
   - `<gallery>`, `<noinclude>`, `<onlyinclude>`, `<translate>`, `<tvar|>`, `<languages/>`: Various tags for special formatting or functions, such as image galleries, conditional text inclusion, translation, variable content, and language support.

Overall, these elements are typically used in environments where markup and specialized formatting are needed, such as in wikis like those powered by MediaWiki (the software behind Wikipedia), documentations, or content management systems.

Edit-Translate
Map data allows users to store GeoJsoN data on wiki, similar to images. Other wikis may use this data to draw on top of the maps, together with other map customization s.

To create a new map data, go to Wikimedia Commons, and create a new page in the Data namespace with the .map suffix, such as Data: Sandbox/Name/Example.map . F experiment by creating pages with the sandbox/<username>/ prefix. For now, page content can only be edited in the raw JSoN format. Eventually, we hope there will be a p editor to simplify GeoJSON creation.
Data licensing [edit]
All data intheData:namespace must licensed underone of the following licences:

.CC0-1.0

 ·CC-BYverSi0nS:CC-BY-1.0.CC-BY-2.0.CC-BY-2.5.CC-BY-3.0.CC-BY-4.0.CC-BY-4.0+

 ·CC-BY-SAVerSi0nS:CC-BY-SA-1.0,CC-BY-SA-2.0,CC-BY-SA-2.5,CC-BY-SA-3.0,CC-BY-SA-4.0,CC-BY-SA-4.0+

 ·ODbL-1.0
The default license is empty string (e.g invalid license) and when a user tries to save page with invalid license, they will be notified of the allowed licenses.
Top-level fields [edit]
Map data has several required and optional top-level elements:

·The required "license" field must always be set to one of the allowed string values, e.g. "cco-1.o" (see #Data licensing)

 ·The optional "description" field must be set to a localized string value - an object with at least one key-value, where the key is a language code (e.g. "en"), and the 1

 · The optional "sources" field must be a Wiki markup string value that describes the source of the map data

 ·The optional"zoom"field must be an integer between 0 and 18. This value is only used for displaying map on its own page, not when including it in the articles.

 · The optional "latitude" and "longitude" fields specify the center of the map when displaying it on its own page, not when including it in the articles.

 · The required "data" field must be set to the valid GeoJSON content. Per GeoJSON specification, "properties" field may be set for every Feature object. The map properties, such as "title" , "description" , "fill" (color), and others. Additionally, the "title" and "description" fields may be either strings or localize( tabular data). This allows the same map data to appear differently depending on the user's language.
